newsitem.title: NETHERLANDS: Imported feed likely cause of Dutch madcow cases.
newsitem.headline: Imported feed likely cause of Dutch madcow cases.

text.p: The two cases of mad cow disease that have come to light in the Netherlands were probably caused by imports of contaminated feed, Dutch Farm Minister Jozias van Aartsen said on Thursday.
In a letter to the Dutch parliament, Van Aartsen said it was very difficult to trace the exact origin of the feed but it had probably came from another European country.
"There are no signs of causes other than contaminated feed," a spokeswoman for the ministry quoted the letter as saying. "The information we have points to it coming from another country."
Prior to 1994, feed containing animal remains could have been imported into the Netherlands despite a ban on its production in the country, she added.
Van Aartsen also announced tighter controls on the sale of Dutch beef, removing parts of the head from the food chain.
Henceforth, the sale of eyes, brains and spinal chords from cattle will be banned. The move was taken in conjuction with the ministry for public health.

The European Union banned exports of British beef in March 1996 after Britain said mad cow disease, or bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE), could be transmitted to humans who ate infected meat in the form of Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease (CJD).
